comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content: Review of NYTimes articles shows a few mentions around the 4th of July of several games in New York and Chicago. The Waseda Baseball Team website's history page says this was their second tour of the US, and ended 17 victories, 36 losses, one cancellation (forfeit?). The trip lasted from March 28th until August 17th. Brief article on Japan baseball history, describing book "Through a Diamond". Baseball was controversial in Japan at the time. In August when the Waseda team returned, an historic editorial was printed by Nitobe Inazo, comparing baseball's deceipt to picking pockets. (He preferred the manliness and honesty of rugby)

comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content: This photo is discussed in The Commons research thread. When I was digging around, I found that there were only a few (college) teams in Japan, so they often hosted international teams and traveled to play. I'd like to understand exactly how this counted as school credit... were they really learning English? Touring businesses and factories?

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: roketpad: Thanks for posting the results of your research--fascinating!

comment.author: 87914514@N00
comment._content: Hi, as this photo was featured in rocketpad's research projects in theFlickr Commons group, we'd love to have this added to the group pool!

comment.author: 34427466731@N01
comment._content: This image has been used in the indicommons.org post: Research: Japanese Ballers Parade, NY, 1911

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Note the proliferation of umbrellas and parasols in the crowd. The photo was taken during a six-day New York City heat wave that left 146 dead, and killed 600 horses. Story in The New York Times, July 8, 1911: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9505E...
